componenttext: Yes. It's a good question. What we have seen, it's -- again, it's a qualitative answer, what we have seen is those customers that are most advanced in the 10-nanometer development have put more pressure on us to get EUV working. I deduce from that, that -- that is, that 10-nanometer is very difficult to do without EUV. Now could there be upside to that number? We gave you a number, so I'm not going to change that number, but the upside would come from the realization of customers that when they move on with their development, that they'll run into this -- into the same physics issues as our leading-edge customer has actually ran into. And I think that could create an upside. Whether that's an upside in terms of orders or shipments early 2016 or late 2015, I don't know. But what we have learned, and let me say one thing, when we talk about customers, we don't talk about one voice. I mean, what we get back from customers is that the R&D people at the customer side are more and more inclined to look for EUV to solve their complexity issues. The operations people say that is fine if you let them give me a solution that is reliable, that I can use even if it's with low productivity, but that I can design in my production process. So those are the type of discussions that we don't only have with our customers, but our customers also have internally, and that could drive upside. But I'm not going -- not willing and not changing the numbers that we gave you today, but I just gave you a qualitative background.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Sure, that's helpful. And I guess, as my follow-up, I get the uncertainty on the 20, 16, 14 foundry adds, given 175,000 installed by the end of the year, at least shipped on your part. But curious in terms of what you're seeing at 28-nanometer. I believe the industry added roughly 70,000, 80,000 wafer starts in '14. Curious what kind of additions you see there, where it appears as though it's primarily UMC, SMIC quality, as the only guys adding. Would love to, I guess, get your vision for spend there in '15.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Yes. I think you mentioned 3 names, but those are 3 names, and we're talking about multiple systems. So you're talking about not a low-capacity number that we are adding. Those are 3 customers that have the capability to buy multiple systems and put them to work and have the business for it. So it is not marginal. It's a node that definitely grows significantly over 300,000 wafer starts per month the way that we see it. And of course, I cannot go into the details for their customer, what they are buying, and I will not do that. But it's multiple systems per customer.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Our next question comes from Francois Meunier from Morgan Stanley.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: The first one is you've got one slide showing that your laser now is working at 80 watts, which looks like good news to me. I'm just referring to a slide from your CTO, Martin van den Brink, that with 80 watts, you could actually do 1,000 wafers per day and also, the old target of 69 wafers per hour. So is that something we can extrapolate from the 80 watts in your slide?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Well, what you need to remember, when we talk about 500 wafers per day, we talk about an average. So there will be days when there's maintenance on the machine, there's overhead time on the machine. So in order to do 500 wafers per day reliably, you need to be over 500 wafers per day, capability per day. So that's why Martin van den Brink said, "Under the right conditions and if we execute on our upgrade programs and our availability programs, then there will be days when we are closer to 1,000 wafers per day than to 500 wafers per day. But in order to get to the average, you need to have that capability." So it's all pretty much in line and in sync with what we're saying.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Okay. Now maybe more a macro question on the chip sector. I'm sure you still have those access to the lithography machines which are in the field. Have you seen any weakness in terms of capacity utilization in some -- at some of the foundries or IDMs, given what we heard from microchip last week?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: No, we haven't seen that.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gareth Jenkins from UBS.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: One follow-up on an earlier question, if I could. I just wondered, with the change in, I guess, base case or the sensitivity scenarios you put out, Peter, I just wonder whether you could give us a sense of whether EUV will still look to be inserted at 16-nanometer DRAM. And then, just secondly, sorry for the 2, but they're actually short ones. On -- I think I'm right in saying that you said that you expected planar NAND to come through early part of next year. I just wonder, does that mean that there's more still to come through on the 3D NAND side next year and, therefore, maybe some upside as we go through the year?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Okay. With respect to your last question, this is what our expectation is. What we see is that we do not expect the 3D NAND capacity to ramp significantly next year. I mean, there is installed capacity that, of course, needs to be fully utilized. I think that will probably happen next year, but we don't plan that. So if there would be a need for -- so a lot of additional 3D NAND capacity, that will be an upside for us. That's not what we're currently planning. And with respect to planar, yes, we see the capacity additions that currently are being asked, largely going into areas where there is a 2D planar production, and that's where it goes. With respect to EUV insertion. A 19-nanometer DRAM -- you didn't ask 19, you asked 16, but 19-nanometer DRAM, we still think that customers can get around that with, let's say, complex immersion. But at 16-nanometer, it's our -- it's our belief, also based on a discussion with the customer, that we'll move into the EUV territory.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kai Korschelt from Merrill Lynch.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: I had a couple. The first one was, again, I'm sorry about that, a follow-on on the EUV revenue recognition. So I'm just wondering, could we -- could this end up being a sort of a pro-rata revenue recognition depending on milestones situation? Or could it be a bit more binary outcome, where you either recognize majority of revenue for the tools in '15 or '16? Or could it be smoothed, I guess, is my first question? And the follow-up would be on memory. On DRAM, I'm just wondering, from your perspective, how much is the current strength driven by mobile versus PC? And the reason I'm asking is, if PCs were to soften again, do you think that it may impact demand for DRAM tools next year?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Okay. With respect to the rev rec, it's speculative because we are negotiating those terms and conditions, so it could be all of the above, you could say, or everything that you -- all mentioned. But that is a speculative answer, which I don't want to give, really, because it is about what will we be able to negotiate with our customers. And I'd like to repeat what I said, first, it's very important that the customers recognize the value of the machine and that they are also trying to manage their risks in terms of the introduction, in terms of the tool performance, that there are conditions attached which will have certain performance criteria is logical, yes? Now how that will, in the end, look and how severe those will be, we'll just have to see. For us, the most important part is that we have a PO within around 90 million or we're going to be 90-plus million PO value that will be recognized, matter of time, and it is about the introduction of EUV into manufacturing, getting up the learning curve. That's the most important of all because EUV is not about 2015 revenue recognition. It is about '16, '17, '18, '19 and the next decade, which will drive the top line of this company. So it is all about that, not so much about the rev rec of the first few tools. The NAND and the mobile answer. Yes, I think we sometimes discuss this with customers, whether it's mobile-driven or PC-driven. But in this particular case, we simply don't have enough evidence and not enough intelligence to give you an answer, and I don't want to speculate here also. So I'm afraid I have to pass on this answer.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Our next question comes from Andrew Gardiner from Barclays.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Just sort of a higher-level question, looking out into next year, really. For the past couple of years, you guys have been willing to provide us with not only a 1 quarter ahead revenue guidance but also a slightly longer-term normally, say, for the next 6 months. This time around, you haven't done that. I can appreciate the uncertainty around the foundry side, given indecision in parts of the food chain, but it does seem, certainly from an industry perspective and from what you're saying, of course, that spending will need to happen from 1 of the 2 parties involved. So if we combine that with backlog at levels not seen since early 2011, it seems to me that you should have at least a good baseline from which to work for next year. So shouldn't this support year-on-year growth on an underlying basis in the first half of next year, even before we consider EUV? Is this a reasonable starting spot? And are there more details you can provide around what you're classifying as a strong start to next year?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Let me take a crack at this. It's Wolfgang, Andrew. Indeed, there is not enough clarity, visibility and certainty to give you a number, but probably I can summarize a bit from a qualitative perspective. It is a strong start, but that's clear. It's driven by DRAM, but it's also driven by the expansion on capacity on 20, 16, 14. But if you go by the different segments, DRAM and NAND, there's really no significant change. We had a good quarter this year, and our big growth assumptions are pretty stable, around 40% in NAND and about 25% in DRAM. So it shouldn't look all that different on logic, foundry, our non-EUV. You heard about the 3 components. I mean, there's still significant buildout on 20, 16, 14. And then, what people sometimes underestimate is that we have still shipments on 28, and then Peter told you this, there are several customers with significant shipments. Plus, customers are pushing very hard, or at least one customer, to get 10-nanometer in as early as possible, with potential shipments, pilot shipment towards the end of the year as well. So we wouldn't be surprised if that logic, foundry is up year-over-year. Now EUV, we have discussed a lot. That's the big wild card. We know what we think we will ship, but we don't know what we will recognize. In terms of IDM, we have also said that before, that on the current volume node, we had a strong year this year and we'll have a little bit of a weaker year next year. But then, we are ramping into the next node, so that should be flattish. And then, what we sometimes forget in these discussions, field options and services have been improving over the years. So the timing is a wild card. The where and when is a wild card, but in general, we feel pretty good about the year ahead of us.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pierre Ferragu from Bernstein.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: On EUV, so it seems that getting to 500 wafers per day at the end of the year is really the last critical milestone. And if I understand correctly, you need to increase a bit your maximum throughput per day and make sure that you can sustain that kind of level for several days. Could you take us through what's going to be -- what could be challenging in achieving that? So what are, like, the technical difficulties that you are going to face by having this endurance test during -- longer? And maybe take us through how you're going to manage that. Is that something you're doing internally in your own labs? Or is that something your key clients are working on at the moment? And how much control do you have on timing for that? And maybe what would be, like, the news flow we should expect from here on that front?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Yes. Let me answer the last question first. How do we manage this? We manage this not only internally but in very close cooperation with our customers. I mean, EUV is as important to us as it is to our customers or it is as important to our customers as it is to us. So at every site, where customers are getting really serious about EUV, putting into manufacturing environment, we have almost a 1-team approach. So we have to do this because it is complex, it's new. Somebody asked a question about the ecosystem. We need to understand all those elements also, how it relates or if it relates to our lithography performance. So this is how we manage it. It's not in isolation. It's very much with our customers. And so news flow. News flow will also come out of customers. News flow will be, going forward, news flow about performances at customer sites. There will be news flow about orders. That's what you need to look at, and that's what you can expect. Now in terms of what do we look at in terms of making progress and what are the areas, I would refer you to Slide 21 of our presentation. Slide 21 says, in fact, when you want to improve wafers per day and how do we get to more than 500 wafers per day, has 3 elements: it's the element of source power; it's the element of the system availability, which is the source system availability; and the scanner. And the latter is more the integration of the source with the scanner. Now source power has 4 elements that are specifically focused on in terms of development programs and things that we did together with our customers, which is what we call the conversion efficiency, how much EUV light can you get out of the plasma, get out of the tin and out of the CO2 laser. The drive laser power, which I just talked about, the CO2 laser power. It's the dose margin, how much EUV dose do you get stable out of the EUV plasma? It's the laser to droplet control. And when we go to system availability, it's the automation, which is basically metrology and the feedback systems; the lifetime of the collector, which actually, we have made a lot of progress on; the reliability of the droplet generator, which is you could say the tin machine gun, yes; and the drive laser reliability. Those are, again, 4 programs that each have a defined and a very specific set of engineers that are looking at this and that integrate this into the system in the field. And then, of course, you have the scanner, which you could say is the least of our problems. But there is a lot of integration and overhead elimination in terms of time between the source and the scanner. Now it's a long list, but it is, in fact, it's those 12 issues that are shown on Slide 21, all of them contributing to more than 500 wafers per day, more than 1,000 wafers per day and more than 1,500 wafers per day. It is how you need to look at it. And you could argue, it's -- they're all part of a chain and they all need to be improved. One has a bigger impact than the other, but it is -- if you want to get to ultimate 1,500 wafers per day or even 2,000 wafers per day, going forward, then those are the 12 elements that we constantly need to monitor, manage and make real progress on.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Our next question comes from Weston Twigg from Pacific Crest Securities.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Just wanted to clarify on R&D. A year ago, I think you indicated that quarterly, R&D would drop to around EUR 250 million a quarter by the end of this year. Looks like you're guiding it to EUR 260 million, but I think you mentioned earlier on the call that you still hope to hit EUR 250 million in 2015. So I wanted to clarify that, that is the case, and then see if you can tell us when you expect to hit that EUR 250 million a quarter number.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Yes. Certainly, EUR 250 million is the target for 2015. I got to tell you also that a large chunk of our R&D is flexible, so it depends really on projects and programs that we're also doing with the outside world. So it could be -- 1 quarter could be a little bit higher, 1 could be a little bit lower. But that is still the target. As it relates to Q4, we've kept it a bit higher because with all the progress that we're having, we didn't want to limit any of the projects that are ongoing right now. But the target is consistent with what we have said before.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Okay, good. And then, just as a follow-up, on the DRAM side, can you just clarify where you're seeing -- which node, I guess, you're seeing the capacity expansion happen? And can you tell us if it's -- I guess, I'm wondering about the litho intensity, whether it's more space or double patterning-based or litho-edged patterning?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: In DRAM, it's the -- the complexity needs double-patterning solutions. And it's sub-20 nanometers, so we're moving into the 19-nanometer node for the leading edge. But also in DRAM, you see customers having different road maps. You have the most aggressive customers are moving into the 19-nanometer DRAM node, but there are still customers that are in the low 20s. So this is the area. But you are right, those 19-nanometer devices, they need to hold some double-patterning layers, and that is what drives up the litho intensity, and it also creates a situation whereby the wafer out capacity, of course, goes down because you have more layers and you have more multipass patterning. So by definition, if you don't build a new fab, you have fewer wafers out in that industry, which is the reason, I think, one of the main reasons why customers are adding some extra capacity to keep the wafer out capacity basically stable.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Our next question comes from Amit Harchandani from Citigroup.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Amit Harchandani from Citigroup. My first question is really in terms of the improvement and progress that we have seen, particularly with respect to EUV over the last 6 to 12 months. To what -- I understand, you're closely working in cooperation with your key R&D suppliers. Going forward, do you see a need to increase your intensity levels of cooperation or -- with any of the particular suppliers, any particular pain areas that you see at this point of time within your supply chain, not necessarily making a move like Cymer? But are there any areas, still, where you could potentially increase the level of cooperation to accelerate the progress on EUV? That would be my first question.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Okay. It's almost a rhetorical question. Yes, of course, we need to increase the level of cooperation with our suppliers because there's always room for an improvement in that area. But I would say -- generally, I would say the level of cooperation and the depth of the cooperation with our key suppliers is such that we don't need to go that much further. It is more about the clarity, sometimes, of roles and responsibilities on -- in terms of the resolution of some technical issues, but that's normal. We don't need to do anything else. I think we are where we are. We need to intensify the efficiency but not so much more suppliers or a deeper level of cooperation. What we have should be good enough. We just need to move on to industrialization, which means that we need to move out of development stage with our suppliers into a predictable industrial production environment. And that will probably, based on our experience, gives us some additional challenges because when you go into a volume industrial production, then you run into new issues. But that doesn't need any deeper cooperation, it just needs a better and an efficient, more efficient cooperation once we move into volume.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Okay. And just as a quick follow-up, given the new scenario you've outlined for EUV for 2015, does that, in any way, alter your build plan for EUV for 2015? Because I understand, earlier, you had a scenario of even as high as 12 to 15 tools. Based on what you see today with the level of uncertainty that you see on the foundry side, does that, in any way, change your build plans? And how do you go about thinking about building these tools over the next 6 to 9 months?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Well, it hasn't really changed in the sense that we said 1 system per month, but then we just started -- we do this 6 months later. So it changed the build plan in the sense that we asked the modules and the parts to come in 6 months later. That's what it will mean. And so not really -- no fundamental change.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Our next question comes from Adithya Metuku from BAML.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: My questions have largely been answered. Just a quick question on EUV gross margins. If you could comment on those next year. How do you see the progression? And a question on -- and if you could clarify the tax rate. Your tax rates in the last couple of quarters have been better than what we've been expecting. That would be very useful.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Yes. I mean, in terms of EUV gross margin, we are, in general terms, still on the track. But once we are in volume production, somewhere in -- 2 years or so after we introduce the 3350 and ship the 3350, we should get somewhere around the 40% mark. And next year is going to be better. It depends a little bit on the terms and conditions as well. It's going to be much better than what we had in the current year. And we have always said we're shooting for the 20% range. So we'll, hopefully, be somewhere in that range. And the second part of your question was regarding the tax rate. We've always said you should model around 10% for your longer-term model. The last 2 years were driven by onetime events, and it was up 1%. In the year we're currently in, we're expecting somewhere around 6% or so because some of the Cymer-related effects carry into 2014 as well. So 6% this year, and then I would put 10% in the model from '15 on.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Let me break in here and just suggest that we have time for 1 last call, and if everybody -- anybody was unable to ask their question and has -- or has remaining questions, feel free to contact the Investor Relations group, and we'll do our very best to get back to you as quickly as possible. So now Kirsten, if we can have the last question, please?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Our final question comes from Johannes Schaller from Deutsche Bank.

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Wolfgang, you mentioned a good growth in field services and options. I was just wondering, generally, how we should think about that going into next year. I mean, there is probably already a pretty good attach rate for a lot of the field options with the new tools you're selling. How should we think about that? And then, also in the installed base, how much more room is there to grow that?

headline: ASML Holding NV, Q3 2014 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2014
componenttext: Yes. We think you should model that in the low 400s. This year, we'll be somewhere around 400, and then it will grow into the low 400s. And it's driven by service, it's driven by options and it's also driven by bigger upgrades that we're doing in the field right now.
